g.text: monosheet has been grown for the first time on the (0001) surface of the topological
as confirmed by scanning tunnelling microscopy, surface X-ray diffraction, and X-ray
is deposited by molecular beam epitaxy from the crystalline BiTeI
precursor that undergoes decomposition sublimation. The key fragment of the bulk BiI
octahedra, is preserved in the ultra-thin film limit, but exhibits
large atomic relaxations. the stacking sequence of the trilayers and alternations of the Bi—I distances in
the monosheet are the same as in the bulk BiI
spectroscopy indicates a direct band gap of 1.2 eV. The Dirac surface state is completely destroyed and a
new flat band appears in the band gap of the BiI
film that could be interpreted as an interface state.
Two-dimensional (2D) metal halides have been of interest since a long time for their intriguing and tunable
has been studied intensely as a material for nuclear radiation detection applications and its
belongs to the inversion symmetric space group
[I—Bi—I] trilayers (TL’s) which are stacked in a rhombohedral
semiconductor with a gap width of 1.67 eV
which is favorable for potential energy harvesting
presence of a high-Z element (Bi) spin-orbit coupling (SOC) is significant and new functionalities are expected
by reducing the crystal’s dimensionality to the ultra-thin film limit which might involve a symmetry lowering, for
instance by the loss of the inversion center induced by atomic relaxations.
Up to now, only theoretical studies on BiI
monosheets have been carried out which have predicted its sta-
bility and the possibility to tune the band structure by strain
cerning structure and physical properties of BiI
monosheets are available. One standard way to prepare a thin
film of a layered material is cleaving the bulk crystal which in the case of BiI
(vdW) connected sheets. Its disadvantage is that this method neither allows precise control of the film thickness
nor the preparation of a single monosheet. Furthermore, handling of bulk BiI
is hindered due to its notable
Here we establish a different approach by depositing a monosheet of BiI
on the (0001) surface of the topolog-
by using molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) from a Knudsen cell filled with presynthesized
BiTeI single crystals heated to 380 °C. As a result, a stoichiometrically almost exact BiI
decomposition sublimation of BiTeI, as corroborated by X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS), scanning tun-
nelling microscopy (STM) and surface X-ray diffraction (SXRD). In addition, momentum resolved photoemis-
demonstrates the instability of the Dirac topological surface state (TSS) of the Bi
deposition and the appearance of flat band interface states in the direct band gap of BiI
